entry.title: Which CSS measurements to use when
entry.summary:
Should you use em or rem for font sizes? How about margins and padding? Where should you use px measurements?

This article is a great resource and I'm posting it here half to keep it on my own radar. Worth a read every once in a while for any developer who, like me, can get into a habit and forget why I'm coding the way I do.

But don't be too dogmatic. Use what works - generally these guidelines will work best.

One thing this doesn't touch on (but is alluded to in the comments) is calc() - the new CSS "unit" value that allows you to specify distances in calculations that could even mix units. For example, you can add 33% + 20px using calc. And cross-browser support is pretty darn good nowadays (see caniuse).

entry.title: Easy-peasy WordPress carousel using Foundation Orbit
entry.summary:
I'm using a fair amount of pieces from Zurb's Foundation framework lately. Here's a simple way to create a basic image slider in WordPress for your theme, using the Orbit script from Foundation.

Advanced Custom Fields

First, install Advanced Custom Fields on your WordPress site. This is not meant to be an ACF tutorial, but basically, this is what you do:

  • Install and activate the plugin
  • Go to the "Custom Fields" entry near the bottom of the left-hand menu in WordPress. Add a new field group and give it an appropriate name.
  • For this project, add five image fields which will output "Image ID". I usually make the first field mandatory and the others optional.
  • Create a rule for what page (or post type) you want to have the custom fields appear on. I generally use "page = front page".

Hook up Foundation

If you're already using Foundation on your project, that's great! Otherwise, head off to http://foundation.zurb.com/ and download a Foundation pack containing at least the Orbit CSS styles. Personally, I use the SCSS version of Foundation. In any case, make sure that your stylesheet contains the CSS styles for the Orbit slider.

Javascript

Also make sure that your theme is using the correct Javascript files for Orbit. You'll need the basic Foundation javascript file as well as the Orbit-specific javascript. Lastly, see the Foundation Orbit documentation for some tips and tricks as well as the javascript setup to make your slider work. See the "Using the Javascript" section.

OK, putting all this together in your WordPress theme

Now for the meat and potatoes. I've created a Gist with this code to refer to:

Orbit Slider Github Gist

In your theme - perhaps in your front-page.php file - is where that code goes. Here's a breakdown:

<?php $image1 = wp_get_attachment_image_src( get_field('slider_1'), 'home-slider-size' );
  $image2 = wp_get_attachment_image_src( get_field('slider_2'), 'home-slider-size' );
  $image3 = wp_get_attachment_image_src( get_field('slider_3'), 'home-slider-size' );
  $image4 = wp_get_attachment_image_src( get_field('slider_4'), 'home-slider-size' );
  $image5 = wp_get_attachment_image_src( get_field('slider_5'), 'home-slider-size' );
?>

This sets up the variables for each image URL that you've entered in Advanced Custom Fields. Each variable in this case contains an array, the first element of which is the URL for the image. So in order to use these variables, you'll need to write, e.g., echo $image1[0];.

I've also used my functions.php file to define a custom image size for the slider images, called "home-slider-size".

Then we'll write the markup for the Orbit slider:

<ul data-orbit>
  <li>
    <img src="<?php echo $image1[0]; ?>" />
  </li>
  <?php if(get_field('slider_2')) { ?>
  <li>
    <img src="<?php echo $image2[0]; ?>" />
  </li>
  <?php } ?>
  ... and so on ...
</ul>

This way, we have a mandatory first image for the slider (which will just sit there if there are no other images). Subsequent images are optional - so if you don't need to use five different slides at one time, that's OK.

Wrapping up

This is a nice, easy way for clients to manage the slider (if they need one) on the home page of their website. I often have optional captions per slide as well via Advanced Custom Fields.

Personally, I often find that many of the prepackaged WordPress carousel plugins are either overkill, too simple, not customizable enough, or too difficult for clients to use easily. This way they can just go to edit their home page to update the carousel, which is generally pretty intuitive.

entry.title: SCSS Syntax Highlighting in Geany
entry.summary:
I've been trying the Geany text editor / IDE for my web development coding. Geany is a great editor - fast and lightweight with plenty of features - but unfortunately, it doesn't highlight SCSS syntax out-of-the-box.

I did some Google searching and didn't really come up with anything at first (besides a custom fork of the program), so I set Geany aside. SCSS/SASS is pretty mission-critical for my workflow.

Yesterday I had a little more time to try searching again. Maybe I used better keywords, because I came across a couple useful posts:

  • http://lists.geany.org/pipermail/users/2012-October/008346.html
  • http://superuser.com/questions/344441/less-syntax-highlighting-in-geany

Feel free to look over those posts, but here's what I did:

  1. I am using Geany 1.23.1, which is the current version in the Arch Linux repositories

  2. Copy a couple of configuration files into your user configuration directory:

    cp /usr/share/geany/filetype_extensions.conf /home/aaronyoung/.config/geany/filetype_extensions.conf

    cp /usr/share/geany/filetypes.css /home/aaronyoung/.config/geany/filedefs/filetypes.css

  3. Edit the first file: ~/.config/geany/filetype_extensions.conf. Add the SCSS file extension to the CSS line:

    CSS=*.css;*.scss;

  4. Edit the second file: ~/.config/geany/filedefs/filetypes.css. I added this at the top of that file:

    [lexer_properties]
lexer.css.scss.language=1

  5. Now Geany is all set up to highlight your SCSS. However, if you've already tried to open a SCSS file in Geany, it has probably cached the filetype with the old configuration. So open ~/.config/geany/geany.conf and delete the entire [files] section at the bottom. Restart Geany - now it should work fine.

Then find yourself a nice colorscheme. Here's a couple good places to check:

  • https://github.com/codebrainz/geany-themes - a collection of Geany colorschemes
  • https://github.com/robloach/base16-geany - base16 color schemes for Geany (see more about base16)

Enjoy!

entry.title: May 2013 Personal Development Report
entry.summary:
Inspired by a recent episode (I wish I could remember exactly which one) of The East Wing Podcast, I'm going to try to periodically write reviews of what I've been up to - web work I've done, things I'm learning, and what's on the horizon. This first post will be pretty general and hopefully I can be a little more specific next time.

Web

I'm currently plugging away on several WordPress-based websites, as usual. I'm pretty happy with some of the work that's going to be going live soon and I'm in the middle of a freelance project that I'm pretty excited about. I love working with WordPress, but I'm understanding that it's not always the best solution and I'm looking into a few alternatives as well.

Design

I don't consider myself a natural designer, so I try hard to look at great design and figure out what they're doing. Unmatched Style is an interesting blog that showcases great design with some good commentary. I would prefer to go in a more minimalist design route, but ultimately in some cases the client wouldn't prefer that style (or it wouldn't be right for their website). Staying detail-oriented and not over-designing is the key.

Front End

I'm currently rocking SCSS for EVERY project. Preprocessing CSS makes everything easier and better. This has led me to Zurb's Foundation framework, which I'm using on my current projects. I like Foundation and it provides a lot of good starter styles and javascript plugins, but some of it is more than I need. In the interest of keeping things leaner and more manageable locally, I'm considering pruning things down quite a bit. Foundation is not seeming quite as modular as I'd really prefer, so I may build my own assets for a skeleton-style front-end framework, borrowing styles from here and there. The Codrops Blueprints elements look really interesting to me as well.

I want to do more work in Javascript. I do a lot of code snippets in jQuery as well as some more advanced AJAXy stuff, but if I'm interested in building more interactive / engaging interfaces, I'll need to brush up on my plain JS.

Back End

I've been realizing lately that I'm more frontend-y than I'd prefer. Time to get back into some back-end programming. While I do some PHP to add functionality to WordPress themes, I'd like to work on more standalone stuff. PHP is an obvious choice because it's widely used, but I'm intrigued by a couple other languages:

  • Python is a nice and clean, well-supported language. It has obvious uses both on desktop and web.
  • Node.js is pretty young, but can do some amazing stuff. Meteor.js looks like a great framework for Node. It's very interesting to be able to write Javascript for both client and server using the same API's, and the realtime possibilites are exciting.

I'll need to just choose something and do it. Probably working on Javascript would have the most payoff in the future because of the frontend and backend applications.

Personal

I am pretty out of shape, but was able to complete my first triathlon during this month. My main claim to fame is that I had the second best bike -> run transition in the race. My swim leg was surprisingly not awful. I'd like to get in shape for a multi-day bike tour in Central / SE Oregon.

I'm not sure if I'll have time to do that. My days are busy and I have to get work done when I can. A lot of interruptions come up.

That's where things are at the moment. Hopefully I'll have a better report next time around - stay tuned.

entry.title: Access XAMPP from Other Devices
entry.summary:
I've tweaked my web development environment over the last couple days so I can access my local Wordpress websites from other machines on my network. These may include:

  • Other computers running different operating systems / browsers
  • Phones or tablets
  • Virtualbox guest OS's running on my computer

How I'm doing this

  1. Find your local IP address. Mine is 10.1.10.100. You can find this using a command like ifconfig for Linux.
  2. Set up XAMPP, MAMP, WAMP, LAMP, or whatever on your computer. I should point out that I'm using XAMPP on Arch Linux, and I can't guarantee another setup would work like this. If you try this, please leave a comment with your results!
  3. Install Wordpress. I use a Wordpress multi-site ("network") installation to keep things a little more streamlined - when I start a new project, I don't always need to create a new database for it, etc. It all depends on the project, but for normal theme development, this setup works fine.
  4. As you install Wordpress, install it under your local IP address (http://10.1.10.100) instead of http://localhost/
  5. When Wordpress is up, you'll view it at (for example) http://10.1.10.100/wordpress. You can use this same address to access it from any other device on your network.

Drawbacks

The biggest drawback is that this setup requires your local IP address always to be the same. If you take your computer to another network, you'll probably be assigned a different IP address, and there's not much you can do about this. Your Wordpress install won't particularly work, especially if you try to get past the home page. And changing the site URL is not really a quick and easy task when you account for media URLs and permalink-related issues.

In my case, I settled on a "good enough" solution. The benefits of this setup, especially with using Modern IE in Virtualbox, clearly outweigh the drawbacks for me.

I went in to my office and checked which local IP had been assigned to my machine. It was the one I mentioned above - 10.1.10.100. So then I came home, configured my router to serve address in the 10.1.10.xxx range, and assigned my computer the 10.1.10.100 IP address. So I have a working development environment both at home and at the office, which is good enough for me.

entry.title: AutoCorrect common misspellings in WordPress
entry.summary:
One of the minor features that got some press when WordPress 3 came out was that "Wordpress" is now automatically corrected to "WordPress" throughout your website - in post or page content, titles, and in comments. This is in an attempt to maintain consistent branding throughout the product, although some consider it slightly more nefarious. Whatever your opinion, this idea can be handy when building client websites, for the same reason.

For example, one of my current website design clients is a business with a name much like WordPress - a combination of two common words, and they prefer to capitalize the second word. I wanted to make it easy for them to write the word correctly on their site; so I took a look at WordPress' code for doing this autocorrect, and adapted it for my needs. Here you go:

// place in your theme's functions.php
// replace "Myword" with "MyWord"
foreach ( array( 'the_content', 'the_title', 'comment_text' ) as $filter ) {
    add_filter( $filter, 'capital_W_dangit' );
}
function capital_W_dangit( $text ) {
    return str_replace( 'Myword', 'MyWord', $text );
}

What does it do? Simple. It gets the text from the page content, title, and comments - and corrects the spelling of "Myword" to "MyWord". You can set this up to do any search and replace in WordPress.

I'd also like to note that my function name "capital_W_dangit" is chosen here simply because the original (WordPress) function is called "capital_P_dangit". You're not likely to run into conflicts with this naming scheme, but you might be best off namespacing your function names as a matter of habit.

entry.title: Fade to background image in CSS
entry.summary:
(As an aside: I'm not sure this is the best title for this piece. Please feel free to suggest one that will be more useful to search visitors!)

One of the interesting things I decided to do with my latest website redesign is a little fade effect as you scroll down the page. The dark gray website header stays fixed at the top of your browser, and content appears to fade out as you scroll down. Note: Works in Webkit desktop browsers only (Chrome and Safari are the big names here).

If you are using an unsupported browser and don't see the effect live on this page, check the image above to see what I'm talking about.

I've seen this effect a number of times, but usually it's placed against a solid-color background. Essentially, you can use a pseudo-element (:before or :after) in CSS and apply a gradient background; or put a box shadow on the element above, and slide the content underneath that to make it look like it's fading out.

Example with a blue box-shadow so you can see what's going on:

Example with light gray box-shadow: see how the content is sliding underneath the shadow, but appears to fade out?

To do this with a gradient image or a CSS box-shadow, the background needs to be the same solid color as the shadow you're using to cover the content. So you generally don't find this effect against an image background - you would be able to see the shadow no matter what color it is.

So on my website, I'm using this basic technique but there are a few special conditions here. In brief:

  • The content is indeed scrolling underneath a pseudo-element (footer.body:before)
  • The background of that pseudo-element is the same background image that is used on the <body> tag itself. The element actually covers up the entire browser window, so the image will be displayed exactly the same size as it is on <body>.
  • The pseudo-element has a Webkit mask image applied to it, which makes it mostly transparent except for the gradient area directly underneath the header.
  • I have also applied pointer-events: none; to the pseudo element so you can click the links, select text, etc. that is underneath it.

OK, here you go in more depth:

The <body> of my website has a background image applied like so:

body {
background: url('path-to-image.jpg') no-repeat center center fixed; /* fixed, centered image */
background-size: cover; /* image covers the browser window w/out being stretched out of proportion */
}

I have a pseudo-element on my footer that covers the entire window. Then if I use the same background image again, it will be exactly overlaid over the body background. Also, since the pseudo-element covers the window, let's make sure that mouse events are passed through to the content below:

footer.body:before {
content: ''; display: block;
position: fixed; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; /* covers entire window */
background: url('path-to-image.jpg') no-repeat center center fixed; /* fixed, centered image */
background-size: cover; /* image covers the browser window w/out being stretched out of proportion */
pointer-events: none /* pass clicks, hovers, etc. down to content stacked below this element */
/* ... (more coming here in the next step) */
}

Next, I'm going to use a mask image on that pseudo-element with the -webkit-mask property that only works in Webkit browsers. This requires me to take a little side trip to explain CSS mask images.

footer.body:before {
/* ... stuff from previous step ... */
-webkit-mask-image: url('path/to/masker.png');
-webkit-mask-repeat: repeat-x;
-webkit-mask-position: top; }

WebKit allows you to set a mask image on an element. The image itself will not display - rather it will appear to clip the element it is masking. Transparent areas of the image will block or clip the element; non-transparent areas of the masking image will allow the element to show.

Let's use a concrete example: a div with a red background, and an image of a black heart. Applying this image as a mask will result in a red heart appearing on the page. The transparent areas of the image hide the red background and the non-transparent heart area of the image will allow the red area to show through.

Make sense?

Demo

Here's a demo of the effect. Feel free to play with it to see what's going on.

Check out this Pen!

Webkit desktop browsers only

Let me break this down. This doesn't work for everyone, so I have to be careful about how I implement it.

  1. My footer.body:before only displays in Webkit browsers. It covers the entire browser window, and I don't want it to display in other browsers because the mask image only works in Webkit. I've added a "masking" class to <body> with a Modernizr-like Javascript snippet.
  2. Touch devices don't handle fixed background images and fixed position elements the same way that desktop browsers do. So I have used Modernizr to detect touch devices, and I don't display the footer.body:before element on those devices.

In both these cases, I have acceptable fallbacks in place.

Anyway, this is a fun, not-too-useful little trick. Hope you enjoy it.

entry.title: New site and 2013 Goals
entry.summary:
Happy New Year!

Welcome to the new and improved AJY.co! This is the time of year that one redesigns one's website and ponders the year ahead.

What's coming up in 2013?

2012 was a very busy year for me. You may know that I'm the Design Director for Opt(e)Web, a small tech company here in Salem, Oregon. Business ramped up steadily throughout the year and we have been challenged to improve our approach to project management and client communication. We've made huge strides and I'm working more efficiently than I ever have. But there's a lot going on, and it doesn't leave me much time for self-improvement, networking, and sometimes a personal life.

From a professional perspective, 2013 is a year of focusing on the improvements I need to make. I'm hoping that my blogging here and over at the Opt(e)Web site can spur me to improve my networking with other web professionals in our area and beyond. So you should expect to see frequent, if not regular, updates on both websites.

At http://opt-e-web.com I will be posting web-related subjects and tips that I encounter in my day-to-day work life. These tips will be focused on one of two audiences: either our customers who, in some cases, may not be particularly web-savvy; or our colleagues in this industry.

Here on this site I will be posting about a wider range of subjects that might interest me. I hope to write about web-related topics as well as Linux and software topics (I'm kind of a Linux hobbyist). Finally, I'll post personal-related blog posts from time to time. FYI, I do have category-specific RSS/Atom feeds.

Also coming up in 2013

  • I am hoping to get back on the bike and in great shape. Time will tell if I'm able to work it into my regular schedule.
  • I want to cook more
  • I want to continue getting better at project management and working efficiently
  • I want to network better in the web industry
  • I want to help/mentor an up-and-coming web designer/developer in the area. At this point I don't have time for a full-fledged mentoring program, but occasional coffee meetings would be great.

About my new website design

I'm going to go bulleted-list style on this section as well. I plan on writing about many of these features in future blog posts, so I'll just mention them here:

  • The most significant change to my website is actually under the hood. I have switched from Wordpress to Pelican, a static blogging engine. Basically, I have a folder full of Markdown files on my computer. Each text file is a post or page of my website; when I write a new post, I run Pelican and it regenerates my site. It creates static HTML files, so my website should be pretty fast since there's no database involved.
  • New design, of course. Make my logo and name smaller, people aren't here to stare at them. Use more cutting-edge technologies - the logo is SVG, for example.
  • This is kind of fun. Notice that if you scroll down, the header stays fixed at the top of the page. The content section of the website fades to the background photo just under the header. This is a trick I'll definitely write about soon, because I haven't seen anything quite like this elsewhere.
  • Also, if you scroll down, try clicking on a blank spot in the dark gray header. It'll scoot you right back up to the top of the page. This was just a little tricky and I'll write about it later as well.
  • I've dropped about 3/4 of the posts from my old website. I've kept posts that I think may be relevant or posts that have been attracting a decent amount of traffic.
  • Still to do: I'm getting a website search function going pretty soon. You'll see it at the top of the right sidebar.

Come along for 2013!

I have a lot to do! If any of the blog topics that I mentioned seem interested (or if you feel like it) I'd love to have you subscribe or get in touch:

  • Google Plus is becoming my preferred social network. Add me to your circles!
  • Twitter - I'm fairly active on Twitter too.

  • Contact Me directly or comment below with your questions, comments, and suggestions.

entry.title: Designing for Clients
entry.summary:
I recently submitted an initial website design for one of our Opt(e)Web clients to review. The design uses a somewhat unconventional layout, but it has some interesting possibilities for this client, and I think it has the potential to be visually engaging.

But I'm not sure the client likes it that well:

  • The layout, as I said, is a little different.
  • I think the client is having difficulty imagining their information in the mockup I gave them; this may partly be my fault
  • There may be a few "little things" that are getting in the way: the client may not like a particular placeholder image I chose, or they may want some different colors here and there. This ALWAYS happens with every project; I don't think any good designer can deliver the perfect product on the first round.

The web design process has a lot of challenges, and designing for clients is difficult for many reasons. I usually have an incomplete understanding of my clients' businesses and their personal aesthetic tastes don't always match mine. A big part of the job is getting inside my clients' heads. It's not enough to build a site that looks like their business card - instead, I have to craft a design that will meet their business needs, represent who they are, and present (usually) a lot of information in a way that is informative and useful to website users.

So when I try something new - such as this website layout - I have to make sure it will work for the client. Sometimes I guess wrong. I'm still holding out hope for the design in this situation, albeit with some modifications. And, as usual, there's something to learn from this project.

What can I do differently?

I should have filled the mockup (it's a coded site) with information and pictures that relate to the client's site. Even though I don't have any of their actual content yet, I should have take more time to find some related text and photos.

Maybe in this case, I ought to have called the client instead of sending an email with the mockup link. That's a really tough call, since you have to know how best to communicate with specific clients.

When I talk to the client, I'll try to talk up the possibilities and potential I see in the design.

But it's important to remember not to get too personally invested in a design concept. It's not my design; it's my client's design.

entry.title: Escaping GoDaddy and Domains by Proxy
entry.summary:
I've decided to pull my domain names out of GoDaddy for various reasons. I've been planning it for some time, but inertia is strong. The final straw came today when I found out GoDaddy is supporting the SOPA act. But that's not what this post is about. One of my domains from early on had "Private Registration", meaning that WHOIS info is not displayed for that domain (I've since decided I don't really care about that). GoDaddy manages their Private Registration through a sister/child/whatever company called "Domains By Proxy".

The Process

To transfer my domain, I need to remove private registration. To remove private registration, I need to log in to my Domains By Proxy account. Whenever I purchase private registration through Godaddy, it's supposed to send me a customer number for Domains by Proxy (note the wording there). So to log in to Domains By Proxy, I have to find an email from GoDaddy with my customer number. I found (via online search) that the password is the same as my GoDaddy password. Then I log on to Domains By Proxy, remove private registration, unlock my domain in Godaddy, and get the transfer authorization code.

The Problem

None of the emails I have on record from GoDaddy contain any mention of my Domains By Proxy login information. I've seen other accounts where people haven't received their information either. I don't believe I have deleted these emails, I am generally good about keeping them. I'm pretty sure I never received them. I tried logging on to Domains By Proxy with my GoDaddy login info, and that did not work. I also tried to retrieve my DBP customer number by going through the "forgotten my login information" form. But it didn't work, which was my fault-- I had originally registered the domain with an old email address that no longer exists. So I presume that DBP was trying to send info to that email address. At this point I was getting a little discouraged and was about to fill out the huge form at Domains By Proxy that requires me to prove my identity by faxing them a copy of my drivers license and requires a three-day waiting period.

The Solution

Luckily, I found a search result that gave me the following tip:

  • In the GoDaddy product overview page, select another domain name and start the process to add Private Registration to it (click "Add" in the Private Registration column for a domain that doesn't have it).
  • In the modal window that pops up, near the bottom is a prompt that says "Select your Domains By Proxy account"
  • There should be a choice that contains your customer number (8-ish digits). Use that customer number to log on to Domains By Proxy, and use your GoDaddy password. Go crazy.

entry.title: Protecting your personal privacy and reputation with social media
entry.summary:
Personal privacy online is a hot topic in today's social media world. Facebook's privacy settings are notoriously complicated and constantly changing. Google Plus and Twitter use simpler - but radically different - paradigms for user privacy, and location-based networks such as Foursquare introduce other privacy concerns. Reputation management is closely tied in with privacy as well; suppose that a Facebook friend tags you in a potentially incriminating photo.

Because of the complexity of trying to manage "who can see what", especially on multiple social networks, I personally favor a "keep it simple" approach:

Post everything publicly; and assume everything you post is public.

So what does this mean?

Choose carefully what you post online, and post it publicly

Only post a status, photo, or video if you're OK with the whole world seeing it. If you're not OK with that, don't post it. Remember that anything you post CAN BE directly or indirectly shared with the whole world. Might as well put it out there to start with, right?

Whatever you choose to post can (and likely will) be viewed in a job search, by a co-worker or boss, pastor, potential date, parents, family, and more. It's a no-brainer that you need to think about what you post instead of relying on Facebook to protect it.

Additionally, when I post publicly, it removes the temptation to post something that could be harmful or hurtful if it gets out. For example, I'd love to post horror stories about some of my web design clients. But that's professionally a bad idea and the story could make its way to those people.

If you have something private to discuss with another person, Twitter & Facebook both have good private-messaging systems. Email and the phone work too.

Also: Check over your Facebook profile. Is your phone number shared publicly, or just with friends? What's your current job, and who can see that? Most of the Facebook setttings are "Friends", "Friends of Friends", or "Everyone". Choose carefully - but remember that even if you put restricted settings on some parts of your profile, they can still get out there if someone shares them. Are you OK with that? If not, take it down and hope nobody has already shared it.

Try to control what other people can say about you

Now what you're all waiting for - actually digging into Facebook's privacy settings. Click the little triangle at the top right of your Facebook page and choose "Privacy Settings". Make sure - like above - your default status is "public".

"How you Connect" and "How Tags Work"

Here are my settings for these sections (click each to enlarge):

As you can see, the idea here is that anything I post is public (that is, filtered before I post it). Then, I restrict others from tagging me in photos, checking me in to places (even if I'm not there), etc. - so it reduces the risk that someone can negatively impact my reputation in this way.

Kudos to Facebook for seriously revamping this interface - but it's still needlessly complicated.

Also: Be careful of approving Facebook apps since they can access and share your information. I got an app request the other day for some birthday calendar thing. Uh, no thanks.

Privacy is your responsibility

Don't rely on Facebook, Twitter, or Google+ to protect your privacy. Anyone can share your information from those sites with the whole world - and we haven't even mentioned what these large companies may do with your data. Did you know that all public tweets are archived in the Library of Congress?

I always assume anything that goes online is out of my control - therefore, I need to control it before it gets there. Posting my status publicly helps me to do that and it puts me in the right mindset when I hit that "Post" button.

Do you have anything to add? Write a comment! Of course, remember, everyone can see it!

entry.title: Sans-serif
entry.summary:
Chris Coyier's post at CSS-Tricks on the sans-serif CSS font stack got me thinking. When I see things like this, I usually think, "That's a cool hack, but how will it work on the many different platforms?" Especially Linux, since I'm a Linux user.

For quick reference, here's what he says:

font-family: sans-serif; /* don't specify Helvetica or Arial */
  • Macintosh PC's get Helvetica by default, which is awesome
  • Windows PC's get Arial by default, which is good because Helvetica doesn't look good on Windows
  • All others get the browser's default sans-serif font by default

Well, Linux is in the "all others" category and there are issues:

  • Ubuntu (the most used distro) uses the Ubuntu font by default. It's a nice font but has a different character, and more importantly, different metrics from Helvetica/Arial
  • Many other distros use DejaVu Sans by default. Also nice (and more generic than Ubuntu), but it also has different metrics than Helvetica/Arial

I personally like Liberation Sans quite a bit. It's a great sans-serif font that is metrically equivalent to Helvetica and I find it nicer than Arial. It's installed on many Linux distros by default, so here's a simple modification that will make things just a little more uniform for many (not all) Linux users:

font-family: 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif;

While I haven't tested Liberation Sans on a Mac or Windows machine, MOST Mac and Windows users aren't likely to have it installed and, like I say, I prefer it over Arial, so it's OK if they do.

This still doesn't address mobile devices much, especially if they use Droid Sans by default (which I find characteristically a little closer to Trebuchet MS than Helvetica).

Last note: I'd personally only do this for body text, where different fonts aren't likely to break your layout. Menus, headlines, etc - be more specific about your font choice.

Anyway, those are my thoughts. Cheers.

entry.title: Stop autosaving and post revisions in Wordpress
entry.summary:
Just a quick post. Wordpress's autosave and revisioning system has its good points but there are several reasons you may want to disable it. Just be aware of the potential consequences - you're more apt to lose work if you don't save consistently.

That said, I do this for nearly all the Wordpress sites I build.

The following code goes in the wp-config.php file, just before the "that's all, stop editing, happy blogging" line:

define('WP_POST_REVISIONS', false);define('AUTOSAVE_INTERVAL',7200);

Technically, this doesn't disable autosave - it sets the autosave interval to two hours.

entry.title: Web Designers - Skeleton Wordpress Theme in HTML5
entry.summary:
Update: My Skeleton wordpress theme has evolved quite a bit since this post. It's not up to date at Github anymore, sorry. The theme has almost completely changed although many of the principles I outline here are still in place.

Another great place for you to find a skeleton theme is from Automattic themselves: See the Underscores theme.

Back to the article

This is the blank Wordpress theme that I use as a development basis. When I design new websites, I start with this set of files and add, subtract, or rearrange code as needed. I thought I'd share it in case anyone finds it useful.

View files or Download theme at Github

Here's what's in the theme:

  • A set of all the core files in standard Wordpress themes: header.php, footer.php, index.php, etc. Includes archive and search templates and all the usual stuff.

  • I use stylesheets a little differently as a matter of convenience to me: The standard WP style.css contains ONLY theme information and a comment. All the styles for the site are in the CSS folder, and the header.php contains links to those stylesheets. I have three stylesheets in that folder:

    1. style.css - contains all the styles for the website. I use the Mo'Bulletproof @font-face syntax, which I've found to have the best cross-browser compatibility. I've switched to the new sparkly Fontspring @font-face syntax now!
    2. reset.css - based on the Toucan CSS Reset and including a lot of Less Framework concepts (like media queries for different screen sizes), plus some custom classes for a quasi-grid. There's actually a fair amount of stuff going on in this file. It is @import'ed into style.css.
    3. ie.css - Currently included with a "less than IE 9" conditional statement. This might need to be changed.

  • A custom functions.php file that contains a lot of stuff that I've found in various places. Includes: A custom excerpt, code to clean out the <head> of various metadata, support for shortcodes in text widgets, etc.

  • There's a function in functions.php to include only one copy of jQuery (from Google's CDN). This is nice because plugins tend to include their own copies of jQuery and sometimes that causes conflicts.
  • There's a scripts/custom.js file for all your custom javascript code.
  • The theme supports Wordpress 3 Custom Menus - create a menu in WP's admin section, and add it as a widget in one of the widget areas, which leads me to...
  • There are four widget areas: Header, Nav, Sidebar, Footer. These are places that I often like to stick widgets like text boxes. The Nav widget area is a great place to put the WP3 Menu that you create, like I said.
  • HTML5!! The theme uses HTML5 semantic elements throughout. There's no wrapper div - instead the main header, section, and footer all have "class='body'". This usually works well as a faux-wrapper and is more semantic.
  • There are a couple template html files that I use while designing the site so I don't have to have LAMPP running all the time in the early development stages. This allows me to tweak my document structure and to style various elements: template.html is a pretty much blank document, while template-example.html contains a bunch of filler text and various elements (h1, h2, del, etc.). This filler text is taken from the Toucan CSS Reset demo.

There's nothing groundbreaking here. I've compiled stuff from a lot of different sources:

  • The theme is based heavily on Chris Coyier's [Blank wordpress theme][] (originally in HTML4, but I've HTML5'd it up)
  • A few resources from (and originally inspired by) Amber Weinberg's Hijinks theme
  • several of the functions from functions.php are from the Digging into Wordpress articles one and two on customizing your functions.php
  • As noted above, my CSS reset is based on Toucan CSS Reset
  • I'm using a lot of stuff also from the Less Framework, primarily media queries which allow the site to adapt to different screen sizes.
  • Some resources from HTML5 Boilerplate and related projects.
  • Other miscellaneous tidbits from different places scattered about the Intertubes.

Issues:

  • functions.php needs to be cleaned up a little more
  • I may not be using HTML5 semantic elements correctly.
  • You may not find this minimal enough for your use - too much markup, etc. Like I say, for me it's a good starting place for my projects.
  • My IE conditional statements will need to be tweaked over time
  • There may very well be typos. Though I've been using this for some time, I'm just now working on really polishing it up. So if something doesn't work, let me know.
  • As I'm adding and changing stuff frequently, sometimes I post it before testing (ha!). I'm sure you'll love it if your WP3 menus don't work or something. If I've used it in a live site, it'll work because by that point it'll be tested. Let me know if you find bad code.
  • Other stuff.

As noted above, view files or download the theme at Github if you're interested. Leave a comment, get in touch, etc. if you have issues. Thanks!

Edited to add: I just remembered this: the reset.css file contains box-sizing: border-box; on certain elements. This is a potential gotcha because when you specify width on those elements, it will calculate width to include the border and padding set on the element. See css/reset.css lines \~100-105 for this.

entry.title: @font-face for obscure Linux Browsers
entry.summary:
UPDATE 2/3/2011: A new @font-face syntax has been released into the wild today: The Fontspring @font-face Syntax. This simple syntax looks like this:

@font-face { 
    font-family: 'MyFontFamily';
    src: url('myfont-webfont.eot#') format('embedded-opentype'),
        url('myfont-webfont.woff') format('woff'),
        url('myfont-webfont.ttf')  format('truetype'),
        url('myfont-webfont.svg#svgFontName') format('svg');
    }

I've checked this syntax in Konqueror 4.6 (KHTML) and gtk-webkit, as well as Opera 11 on Linux. Each browser displays the @font-face font correctly. Further testing is needed in some various browsers (including different versions of IE) to determine if everything is working perfectly and how well the syntax performs.

Back to the original article...

@font-face is an increasingly popular method of delivering custom fonts to display online. The syntax for using @font-face in a CSS file is pretty straightforward, but there are a number of cross-browser issues that complicate the matter. I'm going to describe the best syntax I've found that supports the largest number of browsers, including a couple Linux browsers that don't seem to support other syntaxes (is that a word?) that I've found online.

"Obscure"?

I didn't check just now, but I'm sure Firefox is the most popular Linux browser. There are, however, a number of people in the Linux community who harbor a dissatisfaction with Firefox and use an alternative browser. So, while the browsers described here are not widely used overall, they are pretty well-known among Linux users. The browsers are:

  • Konqueror, the KDE web browser. Konqueror uses the KHTML rendering engine, which (back in the day) served as the basis for the now-popular Webkit engine.
  • Epiphany and Midori are Webkit browsers. They both use the new GTK port of Webkit to render pages. While Webkit-GTK is very similar to the Webkit engines that power Safari and Chrome, there are a few minor differences. One of the differences is the treatment of @font-face syntax.

The Basis:

I originally started from Paul Irish's Bulletproof @font-face syntax here: http://paulirish.com/2009/bulletproof-font-face-implementation-syntax/ and modified it a fair amount. That article is good reading and my intent is not to repeat it here. I also don't intend to be speaking with any authority on this subject, I'm just sharing what works for me. Anyway, read that article. A fair amount of what I'm writing is under the assumption you've read it.

Here's the Bulletproof syntax by Paul Irish (happy face and all):

@font-face {
    font-family: 'Graublau Web';
    src: url('GraublauWeb.eot'); /* for IE */
    src: local('☺'),
        url("GraublauWeb.woff") format("woff"),
        url("GraublauWeb.otf") format("opentype"),
        url("GraublauWeb.svg#grablau") format("svg"); /* these are for other browsers */
    }

My process - Issues and Resolution:

  • In my testing, it seems that GTK-webkit chokes on "local" and doesn't read the rest of the final "src" line above. Therefore, @font-face doesn't work. To resolve this, I moved "local" to a new "src" line. This makes IE choke (that is, the custom font does not display), but I'll take care of it later:

    src: url (...the eot filesrc: local('☺');
src: url(...lots of stuff

  • Then I found that no matter where the "local" declaration is, Konqueror chokes. So I just got rid of it. IE still chokes.

  • To fix IE, I use a conditional comment to include the IE declaration separately:

    <!--[if IE]>
    @font-face {
        font-family: 'Graublau Web';
        src: url('GraublauWeb.eot');
    }
<![endif]-->

    I actually just put this in a separate IE stylesheet. This isn't a problem for me since I almost always use a specific IE stylesheet. My normal stylesheet contains:

    @font-face {
    font-family: 'Graublau Web';
    src: url("GraublauWeb.woff") format("woff"),
        url("GraublauWeb.otf") format("opentype"),
        url("GraublauWeb.svg#grablau") format("svg");
    }

Browser Support:

I tested this in:

  • Firefox 3.6 (Linux)
  • Opera 10.5 (Linux)
  • Midori, using WebkitGtk+ 1.1.22 (fixed!) (remember, this browser uses the exact same Webkit engine as Epiphany, Uzbl, Jumanji, surf, vimprobable, etc., etc.)
  • Konqueror 4.4.2 (fixed!)
  • IE6, 7, 8
  • Google Chrome (Windows)

All these browsers display the @font-face font using my syntax above.

IE Gotcha's:

  • Not using a separate IE stylesheet? You won't like this solution, sorry. It requires double declarations.
  • Using the syntax I just described, IE will get a 404 "not found" message as it attempts to download a file that doesn't exist. See Paul Irish's post for more about this issue. See below for the workaround.
  • Microsoft has expressed support for the WOFF format. This is good in the long-term but in the short-term I wonder if it could create more problems with the release of IE9 and the need to support older versions of IE as well. An alternative syntax may be needed to deliver the WOFF font to IE9 and the EOT to earlier versions of IE. Gosh, I hope not.

IE 404 problem:

As I mentioned above, IE gets a 404 as it requests the WOFF font (actually, it requests a really long string that's not even a real address... Paul Irish's post describes this in more detail). The Mo' Bulletproofer syntax by Richard Fink (mentioned below) prevents this so my current syntax is as follows:

<!--[if IE]>
<style>
@font-face { /* I actually put this in my ie.css file */
    font-family: 'Graublau Web';
    src: url('GraublauWeb.eot');
    }
</style>
<![endif]-->
<style>
@font-face { /* this goes in my normal css file */
    font-family: 'Graublau Web';
    src: url(//:) format("no404"),
        url("GraublauWeb.woff") format("woff"),
        url("GraublauWeb.otf") format("opentype"),
        url("GraublauWeb.svg#grablau") format("svg");
    }
</style>

So I use the Mo'Bulletproof syntax in my projects, based on this sort of trial-and-error testing system. Note, I don't usually put these in my HTML files of course, they go in their respective css stylesheets without any conditional comments or HTML tags.

No perfect solution

Whether it's Paul Irish's Bulletproof syntax with a smiley face, or the "url(//:)" in the Mo'Bulletproof-er, both solutions contain code that is only a hack to make IE behave. I don't see a real semantic difference between the two, and I'm OK with double declarations since I have a separate IE stylesheet anyway in my development workflow. In my opinion, the best I can do is to make sure the syntax works for as many users as possible.

entry.title: Avoid the Domain Registry of America!
entry.summary:
So I got a letter in the mail from the Domain Registry of America. Here's the gist of the letter:

  • I have a domain name expiring within a few months
  • I should transfer registration of the domain name to DRoA and renew through them

Here's a scan of the letter (click for bigger):

The letter itself seemed kind of shady and after Googling the company, I'm pretty annoyed with their "marketing" tactics:

  • The letter has a large heading in the top right that says "Domain Name Expiration Notice". While I suppose the letter is, in a sense, a notice that I have a domain name that expires (fairly) soon, it's misleading because it implies the company has some sort of authority on what will happen with my domain name and that I should take immediate action with them.
  • The bottom third of the letter is a detachable payment form where I can fill in my credit card info and a couple other things and (I guess) automatically transfer/renew the domain name with DRoA. Again, it appears misleading because it looks like a bill. They do note (in the middle of the letter) that "This notice is not a bill" but the letter seems to be formatted to take advantage of people who scan and act immediately.
  • Wikipedia mentions that the company is located in Canada but has a mailing address in Buffalo, NY. Not a problem, but odd for a company called "Domain Registry of America" and the separate mailing address gives off bad vibes.
  • Wikipedia also says the following [quoted directly from the article]: "In 2003, the Federal Trade Commission reached a settlement with the company for practices such as transferring domain registrations to their service under the guise of domain renewal, a practice known as domain slamming, and having hidden fees. Despite this action, the company still sends mass direct mail to consumers resembling invoices with 'domain name expiration notice' in bold print."
  • One more Wikipedia quote: "They have also now (Aug 2009) started emailing potential customers with an email scam, purporting to indicate that the transfer of a domain is 'not complete at this time', and requesting the domain owner follows a series of steps to complete the transfer to DRoA. These are highly misleading emails."
  • They charge \$30 to register a domain name for one year. Many companies charge 1/3 to 1/2 that price, including my current registrar.

So... what to do?

  • Note, I'm not calling this a "scam" though that word has been used by others in connection with this service. However (even without any research), I would guess that they actually provide the service they advertise.
  • If you get a letter or email from this company or another, remember where you've registered your domain name and who you SHOULD be receiving notices & bills from.
  • Read the letter carefully.
  • Rather than renewing your domain name by clicking links in your email, instead use your browser and go directly to the site where you registered the domain.
  • It is OK to transfer a domain name if you want, there's no problem with that. There are many other registrars that do a good job and are competitively priced. And that don't spam people with misleading letters.

In defense of the DRoA, I would imagine it's tough to market domain registration services in a way that's interesting and creative ;).

entry.title: Thoughts on owning a website
entry.summary:
Earlier today, I was writing up a web design client info sheet. I was kind of proud of a couple parts of it, so I thought I'd paste them in here:

Having a website should be a responsibility.

  • You should check the entire site from time to time to make sure that information is current and accurate.
  • If you have dates on your site, they should be kept current. For example, a blog or news section should be updated frequently and regularly. If the most recent news item is from sometime in 2006, the site will not be credible to viewers.
  • In the same way, people change over time. If you have photos of staff or other people on your site, the photos should be kept current.
  • Don’t spread yourself too thin - don’t take on more than you can handle in a website. If you have two blogs, a news section, recent photos, and a section of restaurant reviews, you probably will be burned out trying to keep it all up-to-date.

Use your site as a part of your marketing strategy.

  • Maintain other marketing materials as well, not everyone is online
  • Reference your site in your other marketing materials
  • Make sure that your site exists for your customers, not for you. Consider why people are coming to your site and what information they will be looking for - and make this information easy to get. For example, on a software download site, users probably won’t want to read a long statement about the history and development of the software - instead, the “Download” button should be prominently displayed and the download process should be simple.

Do you like your site well enough that it can replace Google as your home page? I actually enjoy browsing through my own site. I figure, if I like it so much, my target audience should also. Of course, this is a general statement, but it’s a good rule of thumb.

entry.title: Google Maps route elevation profiles
entry.summary:
Welcome! Note that this article is several years old. Please excuse me for pointing out things that are more obvious now... like how to plot a route on Google Maps :) The GPSVisualizer tip partway through the article is still good and I use it regularly.

This isn't anything I've made, but it's a cool combination of tools I came across for mapping running and biking routes and finding their elevation profiles.

Google Maps introduced a very cool "routes" feature a while back that allows you to find directions between two points, and drag that route around to find alternate routes. You can add intermediate destinations or "node" points along the route. I've been finding distances of potential biking routes by simply using Google Maps.

Once at the Google Maps website, right-click at the starting point of your route and choose "Directions from Here". Follow your route to major intersection, and right-click on the map again and choose "Directions To Here". Google Maps will automatically fill in a suggested route. If you don't like it, click and drag it until it's the route you'd like to take between those two points.

After this, find another point along your route and choose "Add Destination". Again, adjust the route if you want. Google will usually choose the most direct driving route from point to point. Keep adding more destinations until you're at the finish!

Usually you can map a lengthy run with 5-10 destinations. This is MUCH quicker than using route mapping tools like the USATF running route tool, where it draws a straight line between each point you click on the map. The drawback is that routes are more limited to roads, so this would be pointless on a trail route.

So now you have a nice running or cycling route, with accurate distance. Now, directly above the map, you'll see the words "Print, Send, Link" in the blue bar. Click "Link" and copy the email/IM link given. Head over to http://www.gpsvisualizer.com and click "Draw a profile" in the top menu.

Find the box that says "Or provide the URL of Data on the Web" at bottom right of the page. Paste your map link here. This site will generate an elevation profile graph of the route.

It only takes a few minutes to do this. I might consider working something like this into a future version of TrueGoal.
